projectDesc.p: "" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

body.lg: <l n="1>Jhesu, that ys kyng in trone,Jesus, who is king on the throne,<l n="2>As thou shoope bothe sonne and mone,as You shaped both the sun and the moon<l n="3>And all that shall dele and dyghte,and all that will judge and govern,<l n="4>Now lene us grace such dedes to done,bestow upon us grace to do such deeds<l n="5>In thy blys that we may wone,that we may dwell in Your exultation.<l n="6>Men calle hit heven lyghte ;People call it the heavenly light.<l n="7>And thy moder, Mary, hevyn qwene,And Your mother. Mary, heavenly Queen,<l n="8>Bere our arunde so bytwene,intercede on our behalf —<l n="9>That semely ys of syght,[Mary], who is beautiful to look at —<l n="10>To thy sone that ys so fre,with Your Son, who is so noble,<l n="11>In heven with hym that we may be,so that we may be with Him in Heaven.<l n="12>That lord ys most of myght.That Lord is the most powerful.

<l n="13>Menstrelles, that walken fer and wyde,Entertainers who walk far and wide,<l n="14>Her and ther in every a syde,here and there, everywhere,<l n="15>In mony a dyverse londe,in many a different country,<l n="16>Sholde, at her begynnyng,should [first], when they start,<l n="17>Speke of that ryhtwes kyng,speak of that righteous King<l n="18>That made both see and sonde.who made both the sea and the sand.<l n="19>Whoso wyll a stounde dwelle,Whoever would like to stop and linger:<l n="20>Of mykyll myrght y may you telle,I will tell you of much joy,<l n="21>And mornyng ther amonge,interspersed with sorrow,<l n="22>Of a lady fayr and fre,of a fair and noble lady.<l n="23>Her name was called Emare,Her name was Emaré,<l n="24>As i here synge in songe.as I am singing here in song.

<l n="25>Her fadyr was an emperour,Her father was an emperor<l n="26>Of castell, and of ryche towre,overseeing castles and splendid strongholds,<l n="27>Syr Artyus was hys nome ;Sir Artyus was his name.<l n="28>He hadde bothe hallys and bowrys,He had halls as well as bowers,<l n="29>Frythes fayr, forestes with flowrys,considerable hunting grounds, forests with flowers;<l n="30>So gret a lord was none.there was no lord as noble as him.<l n="31>Weddedde he had a lady,He had married a lady<l n="32>That was both fayr and semely,who was both fair and beautiful,<l n="33>Whyte as whalës bone,white as whalebone:<l n="34>Dame Erayne hette that emperes,Dame Erayne that empress was called.<l n="35>She was full of love and goodnesse,She was full of love and virtue,<l n="36>So curtays lady was none.no lady was as courteous.

<l n="37>Syr Artyus was the best manneOf all men that were alive then<l n="38>In the worlde that lyvede thanne,Sir Artyus was the most excellent.<l n="39>Both hardy and therto wyght,[He was] both valiant and brave.<l n="40>He was curtays in all thyng,He was courteous in every respect,<l n="41>Bothe to olde and to yynge,both to the old and to the young.<l n="42>And well kowth dele and dyght.And he was able to judge and govern well.<l n="43>He hadde but on chyld in hys lyve,He had but one child in his life,<l n="44>Begeten on hys weddedde wyfe,conceived with his wedded wife,<l n="45>And that was fayr and bryght ;and [the child] was fair and radiant.<l n="46>For sothe, as y may telle the,Truthfully, I can tell you,<l n="47>They called that chyld Emare,they called that child Emaré<l n="48>That semely was of syght.who was beautiful to look at.

<l n="49>When she was of her moder born,When she was delivered from her mother,<l n="50>She was the fayrest creature borne,she was the fairest creature born<l n="51>That yn the lond was thoo,[and alive] in that country.<l n="52>The emperes, that fayr ladye,Then the empress, that fair lady,<l n="53>Fro her lord gan she dye,was parted from her lord by death<l n="54>Or hyt kowthe speke or goo.before she [Emaré] could walk or talk.<l n="55>The chyld, that was fayr and gent,The child, who was beautiful and noble,<l n="56>To a lady was hyt sente,was sent to a lady<l n="57>That men called Abro,who was called Abro.<l n="58>She thawghth hit curtesye and thewe,She taught her courtly manners and good conduct,<l n="59>Golde and sylke for to sewe,how to embroider with golden and silken threads,<l n="60>Amonge maydenes moo.alongside other young girls.

<l n="61>Abro tawghte thys mayden small,Abro taught this small maiden<l n="62>Nortour that men usedenn in sale,the correct manners to be used in the dining hall,<l n="63>Whyle she was in her bowre ;while she was staying in her quarters.<l n="64>She was curtays in all thynge,She was courteous in every respect,<l n="65>Bothe to old and to yynge,both to the old and to the young;<l n="66>And whythe as lylye flowre ;and [she was] as white as a lily-flower.<l n="67>Of her hondes she was slye,She was skillful with her hands.<l n="68>All he loved that her sye,All who saw her loved her<l n="69>Wyth menske and mychel honour.with honor and much respect.<l n="70>At the meydene leve we,Here we shall leave the maiden<l n="71>And at the lady fayr and fre ;and the fair and noble lady,<l n="72>And speke we of the emperour.and speak of the emperor.

<l n="73>The emperour of gentyll blode,The high-born emperor<l n="74>Was a curteys lorde and a gode,was a courteous and just lord<l n="75>In all maner of thynge,in every respect.<l n="76>Aftur when his wyf was dede,Later, when his wife had died,<l n="77>And ledde his lyf yn weddewede,and he led his life as a widower,<l n="78>And myche loved playnge.he much liked to keep himself amused.<l n="79>Sone aftur yn a whyle,Some time later,<l n="80>The ryche kynge of Cesylethe powerful king of Sicily<l n="81>To the emperour gann wende,made his way to the emperor.<l n="82>A ryche present wyth hym he browght,He brought a costly gift with him,<l n="83>A cloth that was wordylye wroght,a fabric that was made skillfully.<l n="84>He wellcomed hym as the hende.He [the emperor] received him in a courtly manner.

<l n="85>Syr Tergaunte, that nobyll knyght hyghte.Sir Tergaunte was the name of that noble knight.<l n="86>He presented the emperour ryght,He offered a gift to the emperor in a courtly manner ,<l n="87>And sette hym on hys kne,having bent down on his knee:<l n="88>Wyth that cloth rychyly dyght,a cloth that was richly ornamented.<l n="89>Full of stones ther hit was pyght ,It was bejeweled over and over with stones,<l n="90>As thykke as hit myght be,as densely as possible,<l n="91>Off topaze and rubyes,with topazes and rubies<l n="92>And other stones of myche prys,and other stones of great worth<l n="93>That semely wer to se,that were beautiful to look at,<l n="94>Of crapowtes and nakette,with toadstones and nakettes.<l n="95>As thykke ar they sette,They are set so thickly,<l n="96>For sothe as y say the.truthfully, as I am telling you.

<l n="97>The cloth was displayed sone,The fabric was displayed quickly.<l n="98>The emperoer lokede therupone,The emperor gazed upon it<l n="99>And myght hyt not se,and was not able to identify anything on it<l n="100>For glysteryng of the ryche ston—because of the glistening of the precious stones—<l n="101>Redy syght had he non,he did not have ready sight of it ,<l n="102>And sayde, How may thys be ?and [he] said: “How is this possible?”<l n="103>The emperour sayde on hygh,The emperor hastily said:<l n="104>Sertes, thys ys a fayry,“Certainly, this is fairywork,<l n="105>Or ellys a vanytè.Or else an illusion!”<l n="106>The kyng of Cysyle answered than,Then the King of Sicily answered:<l n="107>So ryche a jwell ys ther non“There is no [other] jewel as precious<l n="108>In all Crystyante.in all of Christendom.”

<l n="109>The amerayle dowghter of hethennesThe daughter of the Muslim emir<l n="110>Made this cloth withouten lees,made this cloth, certainly,<l n="111>And wrowghte hit all with pride,and wrought it entirely and honorably<l n="112>And purtreyed hyt with gret honour,and fashioned it with great virtues,<l n="113>Wyth ryche golde and asowr,with precious gold and azure,<l n="114>And stones on ylke a syde ;and [with] stones on every side.<l n="115>And, as the story telles in honde,And, as the story at hand tells,<l n="116>The stones that yn this cloth stondethe stones that are positioned in this cloth<l n="117>Sowghte they wer full wyde,were sought from very far away.<l n="118>Seven wynter hit was yn makynge,It was in the making for seven years<l n="119>Or hit was browght to endynge,before it was completed,<l n="120>In herte ys not to hyde.that is the truth of it.

<l n="121>In that on korner made wasIn that one corner<l n="122>Idoyne and Amadas,Ydoine and Amadas were made<l n="123>With love that was so trewe,with love that was so steadfast;<l n="124>For they loveden hem wit honour,because they loved each other honorably<l n="125>Portrayed they wer with trewe-love flour,they were portrayed with the true-love-flower<l n="126>Of stones bryght of hewe,[made] of stones of radiant hues:<l n="127>Wyth carbunkull and safere,with carbuncle and sapphire,<l n="128>Kassydonys and onyx so clere,chalcedony and onyx, gleaming so,<l n="129>Sette in golde newe,set in new gold;<l n="130>Deamondes and rubyes,diamonds and rubies<l n="131>And other stones of mychyll pryse,and other stones of great worth<l n="132>And menstrellys with her gle.and entertainers with their song.

<l n="133>In that other corner was dyght,In that other corner were assembled<l n="134>Trystram and Isowde so bryght,Tristan and Iseult, so radiant—<l n="135>That semely wer to se,they were beautiful to look at;<l n="136>And for they loved hem ryght,and because they loved each other sincerely,<l n="137>As full of stones ar they dyght,they are composed of so many stones,<l n="138>As thykke as they may be,[set] as thickly as possible,<l n="139>Of topase and of rubyes,[composed] of topazes and rubies,<l n="140>And other stones of myche pryse,and other stones of great worth,<l n="141>That semely wer to se,that were beautiful to look at.<l n="142>Wyth crapawtes and nakette,With toadstone and nakettes<l n="143>Thykke of stones ar they sette,they [Tristan and Iseult] are set thickly with stones,<l n="144>For sothe as y say the.truthfully, as I am telling you.

<l n="145>In the thrydde korner, with gret honour,In the third corner, with great splendor,<l n="146>Was Florys and dam Blawncheflour,was Floris and Dame Blanchefleur,<l n="147>As love was hem betwene,because love was between them.<l n="148>For they loved wyth honour,As they loved honorably<l n="149>Purtrayed they wer with trewe-love-flower,they were depicted with the true-love-flower,<l n="150>Wyth stones bryght and shene.with stones that were bright and luminous.<l n="151>Ther wer knyghtes and senatowres,There were knights and senators,<l n="152>Emerawdes of gret vertues,emeralds of great virtues,<l n="153>To wyte withouten wene,truthfully, no doubt,<l n="154>Deamondes and koralle,diamonds and coral,<l n="155>Perydotes and crystall,chrysolites and crystal,<l n="156>And gode garnettes bytwene.and good garnets in between.

<l n="157>In the fowrthe korner was oonIn the fourth corner was<l n="158>Of Babylone the sowdan sonne,the Sultan of Babylon’s son,<l n="159>The amerayles dowghtyr hym by,the emir’s daughter by his side.<l n="160>For his sake the cloth was wrowght,For his sake the cloth had been made.<l n="161>She loved hym in hert and thowght,She loved him in her heart and mind,<l n="162>As testymoyeth this storye.as this story testifies.<l n="163>The fayr mayden her byfornIn front of the fair maiden<l n="164>Was portrayed an unykorn,a unicorn was depicted<l n="165>With hys horn so hye,with his horn held up so high,<l n="166>Flowres and bryddes on ylke a syde,flowers and birds on each side,<l n="167>With stones that wer sowght wyde,with stones that were sought from far away,<l n="168>Stuffed wyth ymagerye.endowed with [figural] decorations.

<l n="169>When the cloth to ende was wrowght,When the making of the cloth was finished,<l n="170>To the sowdan sone hit was browght,it was brought to the sultan’s son,<l n="171>That semely was of syghte :so beautiful to look at.<l n="172>“My fadyr was a nobyll man,“My father was a noble man;<l n="173>Of the sowdan he hit wan,he gained [the cloth] from the sultan<l n="174>Wyth maystrye and wyth myghth ;with violence and force.<l n="175>For gret love he yaf hyt me,Because of his love, he gave it to me.<l n="176>I brynge hit the in specyaltè,I bring it to you on account ofspecial affection;<l n="177>Thys cloth ys rychely dyght.”this cloth is put together magnificently.”<l n="178>He yaf hit the emperour,He gave it to the emperor.<l n="179>He receyved hit with gret honour,He received it with great honor<l n="180>And thonkede hym fayr and ryght,and thanked him eloquently and appropriately.

<l n="181>The kyng of Cesyle dwelled therThe King of Sicily stayed there<l n="182>As long as his wyll wer,as long as he wished<l n="183>Wyth the emperour for to play,to amuse himself with the emperor;<l n="184>And when he wolde wende,and when he wanted to return home,<l n="185>He toke his leve at the hende,he took his leave immediately,<l n="186>And wente forth on hys way.and went on his way.<l n="187>Now remeveth this nobyll kyng,Now this noble king had departed.<l n="188>The emperour after his dowghter hadde longyng,The emperor had a longing for his daughter,<l n="189>To speke with that may,[he desired] to speak with that maiden.<l n="190>Messengeres forth he sent,He sent messengers<l n="191>Aftyr the mayde fayre and gent,to the beautiful and noble maiden<l n="192>That was bryght as someres day.who was as radiant as a summer’s day.

<l n="193>Messengeres dyghte hem in hye,Messengers hurriedly prepared themselves.<l n="194>With myche myrthe and melodye,With much merriment and music,<l n="195>Forth gon they fare,they went forth,<l n="196>Both by stretes and by stye,by street and by path,<l n="197>After that fayr lady,to that fair lady,<l n="198>Was godely unther gare.[who] was virtuous underneath her garments.<l n="199>Her norysse, that hyghte Abro,Her nurse, who was called Abro,<l n="200>With her she goth forth also,also went with her,<l n="201>And wer sette in a chare,and they were seated in a carriage.<l n="202>To the emperour gan the go,Then they went to the emperor,<l n="203>He come ayeyn hem a myle or two,who went a mile or two in their direction to meet them.<l n="204>A fayr metyng was there.A pleasant meeting was held there.

<l n="205>The mayden, whyte as lylye flour.The maiden, white as a lily-flower,<l n="206>Lyghte ayeyn her fadyr, the emperour,alighted facing her father, the emperor;<l n="207>Two knyghtes gan her lede.two knights led her.<l n="208>Her fadyr, that was of gret renowne,Her father, who was of great fame,<l n="209>That of golde wered the crowne,who wore the golden crown,<l n="210>Lyghte of hys stede ;alighted from his steed.<l n="211>When they wer bothe on her fete,When they were both on their feet,<l n="212>He klypped her ond kyssed her swete,he embraced her and sweetly kissed her,<l n="213>And bothe on fote they yede,and they both walked on foot.<l n="214>They wer glad and made good chere,They were joyous and made good cheer<l n="215>To the palys they yede in fere.and walked to the palace together,<l n="216>In romans as we rede.as we read in romance.

<l n="217>Then the lordes that wer grete,Then the lords, who were distinguished,<l n="218>They wesh and seten doun to mete,washed [their hands] and sat down to eat,<l n="219>And folk hem served swyde,and people served them swiftly.<l n="220>The mayden, that was of sembelant swete,The young woman, who was of a delightful shape,<l n="221>Byfore her owene fadur sete,sat down in front of her own father.<l n="222>The fayrest wommon on lyfe.[She was] the most beautiful woman alive.<l n="223>That all his hert and all his thowghth,[So] all his heart and all his mind<l n="224>Her to love was yn browght,was fixated on loving her.<l n="225>He byhelde her ofte sythe,He gazed at her often.<l n="226>So he was anamored hys thowghter tyll,He was so enamored by his daughter<l n="227>With her he thowghth to worche his wyll,that he schemed how to have his way<l n="228>And wedde her to hys wyfe.and wed her as his wife.

<l n="229>And when the mete-whyle was doun,And when dinner was over<l n="230>Into hys chamber he wente soun,he soon went into his chamber<l n="231>And called his counseyle nere,and called his council in.<l n="232>He bad they shulde sone go and come,He bade them to go and return quickly,<l n="233>And gete leve of the pope of Rome,and get leave from the Pope of Rome<l n="234>To wedde that mayden clere.to wed that beautiful maiden.<l n="235>Messengeres forth they wente,The messengers went forth.<l n="236>They durst not breke his commandement,They did not dare to break his command;<l n="237>And erles with hem yn sere,and earls went with them, too.<l n="238>They wente to the courte of Rome,They went to the court in Rome<l n="239>And browghte the popus bullus sone,and soon brought (back) the Pope’s dispensation<l n="240>To wedde hys dowghter dere.[for Artyus] to wed his dear daughter.

<l n="241>Then was the emperour gladde and blythe,Then the emperor was joyous and happy,<l n="242>And lette shape a robe swythe,and swiftly had a robe shaped<l n="243>Of that cloth of golde,from the gold cloth.<l n="244>And when hit was don her upon,And when it was put upon her<l n="245>She semed non erthely wommon,she did not seem like an earthly woman<l n="246>That marked was of molde.who was created by God.<l n="247>Then seyde the emperour so fre,Then the very noble emperor said:<l n="248>Dowghtyr, y woll wedde the,“Daughter, I want to wed you,<l n="249>Thow art so fresh to beholde.you are so bright to behold.”<l n="250>Then sayde that wordy unther wede,Then that worthy one underneath the clothing said:<l n="251>Nay, syr, god of heven hit forbede,“No, Sir, God of Heaven forbids<l n="252>That ever do so we shulde!that we should ever do so!

<l n="253>Yyf hit so betydde that ye me wedde,“If it so happened that you married me<l n="254>And we shulde play togedere in bedde,and we were to amuse ourselves in bed<l n="255>Bothe we were forlorne ;we would both be lost!<l n="256>The worde shulde sprynge fer and wydeThe word would spread far and wide;<l n="257>In all the worlde on every syde,the news would be carried<l n="258>The worde shulde be borne.into every corner of the world.<l n="259>Ye ben a lorde of gret pryce,You are a lord of outstanding praise,<l n="260>Lorde, lette never suche sorow aryce,[so] Lord, never let such sorrow arise:<l n="261>Take god you beforne ;pay heed to God!<l n="262>That my fader shulde wedde me,That my father should wed me,<l n="263>God forbede that i hyt so se,God forbid that I should witness that,<l n="264>That wered the crowne of thorne!(God) who was adorned with a crown of thorns!”

<l n="265>The emperour was ryght wrothe,The emperor was consumed with rage,<l n="266>And swore many a gret othe,and swore many a great oath<l n="267>That deed shulde she be ;that she must die.<l n="268>He lette make a nobull boot,He had a magnificent boat made<l n="269>And dede her theryn god wote,and put her inside, God knows,<l n="270>In the robe of nobull ble.in that robe of magnificent brightness.<l n="271>She moste have with her no spendyng,She was not permitted to have any spendable wealth with her, nor food, nor drink,<l n="272>Nother mete ne drynke,and he cast her into the sea.<l n="273>Bot shote her yn to the se ;Now the lady remained there for a long time<l n="274>Now the lady dwelled thore,without anker or [steering] oar<l n="275>Wythowte anker or ore,and that was a great misery!<l n="276>And that was gret pytè.There came a wind, I understand,

<l n="277>Ther come a wynd, y untherstonde,and [it] blew her boat away from the shore.<l n="278>And blewe the boot fro the londe,They lost sight of her.<l n="279>Of her they lost the syght,The emperor thought to himself<l n="280>The emperour hym bethowght,that he had done a great wrong<l n="281>That he hadde all myswrowht,and he was a sorry knight.<l n="282>And was a sory knyghte.And as he stood in contemplation,<l n="283>And as he stode yn studyÿnge,he fell down into a swoon,<l n="284>He fell down in sowenynge,he fell down onto the ground.<l n="285>To the yrthe was he dyght ;Great lords stood nearby<l n="286>Gret lordes stode therby,and hastily helped up the emperor<l n="287>And toke yn the emperour hastyly,and comforted him kindly and well.<l n="288>And comforted hym fayr and ryght.When he had regained consciousness

<l n="289>When he of sownyng kovered was,he wept sorely and said, “Alas,<l n="290>Sore he wepte and sayde, Alas,for my dear daughter!<l n="291>For my dowhter dere !Alas, that I was born,<l n="292>Alas, that y was made man,miserable wretch that I am!”<l n="293>Wrecched kaytyf that i hit am ! ǂThe tears ran down his face.<l n="294>The teres ronne by his lere.“I acted against God’s law<l n="295>I wrawght ayeyn goddes lay,towards her, who was so true of faith,<l n="296>To her that was so trewe of fay :alas, why is she not here!”<l n="297>Alas, why ner she here!The tears flooded out of his eyes;<l n="298>The teres lasshed out of his yyen,the high-ranked lords who witnessed this<l n="299>The grete lordes that hyt syyen,wept and displayed their grief.<l n="300>Wepte and made yll chere.Nobody, neither old nor young

<l n="301>Ther was nother olde ny yynge,could abstain from weeping<l n="302>That kowthe stynte of wepynge,for that beautiful one under the cloak.<l n="303>For that comely unther kelle,They quickly rushed onto ships<l n="304>Into shypys faste gan they thrynge,in order to seek the young maiden<l n="305>For to seke that mayden yynge,who was so fair of flesh and skin.<l n="306>That was so fayr of flesh and fell ;They searched for her all over the sea<l n="307>They her sowght over all yn the see,and could not find that noble lady.<l n="308>And myghte not fynde that lady fre,Quickly they came back.<l n="309>Ayeyn they come full snell.We now leave the emperor,<l n="310>At the emperour now leve we,and I shall begin to speak<l n="311>And of the lady yn the see,of the lady at sea.<l n="312>I shall begynne to tell.The lady drifted forth alone;

<l n="313>The ladye fleted forth alone,to God in Heaven she made her complaint<l n="314>To god of heven she made her mone,and also to His mother.<l n="315>And to hys modyr also ;She was propelled by the wind and the rain;<l n="316>She was dryven with wynde and rayn,and opposed by the dark water’s<l n="317>With strong stormes her agayn,fierce storms.<l n="318>Of the water so blo.As I have heard storytellers sing and tell<l n="319>As y have herd menstrelles syng yn sawe,she could neither see settlements nor land;<l n="320>Hows ny lond myghth she non knawe,she was afraid to move.<l n="321>Aferd she was to go,She was tossed from wave to wave.<l n="322>She was so dryven fro wawe to wawe,She hid her head and lay low.<l n="323>She hyd her hede and laye full lawe,The water tormented her.<l n="324>For watyr she was full woo.Now this lady remained there

<l n="325>Now this lady dwelled thorefor a good seven nights and longer<l n="326>A good seven nyghth and more,—as it was God’s will—<l n="327>As hit was goddys wylle,with a heavy heart and sighing loudly;<l n="328>With carefull herte, and sykyng sore,this misfortune was her destiny<l n="329>Such sorow was here yarked yore,and she always lay still.<l n="330>And ever lay she styll.She was driven to a land<l n="331>She was dryven ynto a lond,through the grace of God’s mercy<l n="332>Thorow the grace of goddes sond,which encompasses all things.<l n="333>That all thyng may fulfylle,She had been harassed so severely at sea<l n="334>She was on the see so harde bestadde,that she was almost crazed from hunger and thirst.<l n="335>For hunger and thurste almost madde,Cursed be ill weather!<l n="336>Woo worth wederus yll !She was driven into a land

<l n="337>She was dryven into a lond,that was called “Galys” , as I understand,<l n="338>That hyghth Galys, y untherstond,which was a pleasant country.<l n="339>That was a fayr cuntre,The king’s steward dwelled there beside [the sea]<l n="340>The kynges steward dwelled ther bysyde,in a castle of great worth;<l n="341>In a kastell of mykyll pryde,he was called Sir Kadore.<l n="342>Syr Kadore hyght he.Every day he would go<l n="343>Every day wolde he go,and take a squire or two with him<l n="344>And take with hym a sqwyer or two,and they would amuse themselves on the beach.<l n="345>And play hym by the see ;On one of these occasions he went outside for a walk<l n="346>On a tyme he toke the eyr,with two good and fair knights;<l n="347>With two knyghtes gode and fayr,the weather was pleasant and calm.<l n="348>The wedur was lythe of le.He found a boat by the sea

<l n="349>A boot he fond by the brym,and a glistening thing inside it<l n="350>And a glysteryng thyng theryn,which made them marvel.<l n="351>Therof they had ferly,They went across the sand<l n="352>They went forth on the sond,to the boat, as I understand,<l n="353>To the boot i untherstond,and found that lady inside.<l n="354>And fond theryn that lady.She had been without food for so long<l n="355>She hadde so longe meteles be,that it grieved them greatly to see<l n="356>That hym thowht dele to se,[that] she was on the point of dying.<l n="357>She was in poynt to dye.They asked her what her name was:<l n="358>They askede her what was her name,she changed it there on the spot<l n="359>She chaunged hit ther anone,and said she was called Egaré.<l n="360>And sayde she hette Egare.Sir Kadore felt great compassion:

<l n="361>Syr Kadore hadde gret pytè,he picked up the lady of the sea<l n="362>He toke up the lady of the see,and led her home.<l n="363>And hom gan he lede ;She had been without food for so long<l n="364>She hadde so longe meteles be,that she had grown as lean as a tree,<l n="365>She was wax lene as a tre,that worthy one underneath the dress.<l n="366>That wordy unther wede.When she came into his castle,<l n="367>Into hys castell when she came,they took her into a chamber<l n="368>Into a chawmbyr they her namm,and fed her well<l n="369>And fayr they gann her fede,with all the delicious food and drink<l n="370>Wyth all delycyus mete and drynke,they could think of<l n="371>That they myghth hem on thynke,that was in the castle.<l n="372>That was yn all that stede.When that fair-faced lady

<l n="373>When that lady, fayr of face,was restored with food and drink<l n="374>With mete and drynke kevered was,and had regained her [healthy] complexion,<l n="375>And had colour agayne,she taught them how to sew and embroider<l n="376>She tawghte hem to sewe and markeall kinds of silk work;<l n="377>All maner of sylkyn werke,they were very pleased with her.<l n="378>Of her they wer full fayne.She was courteous in every respect,<l n="379>She was curteys yn all thyng,both to the old and the young,<l n="380>Bothe to olde and to yynge,I tell you, truthfully.<l n="381>I say yow for certeyne ;She was able to fashion all sorts of things<l n="382>She kowthe werke all maner thyng,that would befit an emperor or a king,<l n="383>That fell to emperour or to kyng,earl, baron, or retainer.<l n="384>Erle, barown, or swayne.Sir Kadore arranged for a feast

<l n="385>Syr Kadore lette make a feste,that was proper and appropriate<l n="386>That was fayr and honeste,for his lord, the king.<l n="387>Wyth hys lorde the kynge,There was much entertainment,<l n="388>Ther was myche menstralsè,trumpets, tambourines and zithers,<l n="389>Trompus, tabors, and sawtrè,harps as well as fiddle-playing.<l n="390>Bothe harpe and fydyllyng.The lady who was noble and [yet] lowly,<l n="391>The lady, that was gentyll and small,served in the hall in just her frock<l n="392>In kurtull alone served yn hall,before that noble king.<l n="393>Byfore that nobull kyng,The cloth upon her shone so intensely<l n="394>The cloth upon her shone so bryghth,when she was in dressed in it<l n="395>When she was theryn ydyghth,that she did not seem to be an earthly thing.<l n="396>She semed non erdly thyng.The king gazed at her.

<l n="397>The kyng loked her upon,He had never seen such a beautiful lady before.<l n="398>So fayr a lady he sygh nevur non,She held his heart in her grasp.<l n="399>His herte she hadde yn wolde,He was so enamored of that sight<l n="400>He was so anamered of that syghth,that he was unable to eat<l n="401>Of the mete non he myghth,but quickly fixed his gaze upon her.<l n="402>But faste gan her beholde ;She was so beautiful and noble<l n="403>She was so fayr and gent,that the king’s love was bestowed on her<l n="404>The kynges love on her was lent,as it is told in the tale.<l n="405>In tale as hyt ys tolde ;And when the dinner was over<l n="406>And when the mete-whyle was doun,he went quickly into his chamber<l n="407>In to the chamber he wente soun,and confidently called his barons.<l n="408>And called his barouns bolde.First he called Sir Kadore,

<l n="409>Fyrst he called syr Kadore,and other knights that were present,<l n="410>And other knyghtes that ther wore,to come to him quickly.<l n="411>Hastely come hym tyll,Well-educated dukes and earls<l n="412>Dukes and erles, wyse of lore,hastily came before the king<l n="413>Hastely come the kyng before,and asked him what he required.<l n="414>And askede what was his wyll.Then the powerful sovereign spoke.<l n="415>Then spakke the ryche yn ray ,He started uttering<l n="416>To syr Kadore gan he say,affectionate and secret words to Sir Kadore:<l n="417>Wordes fayr and stylle :“Sir, where is that lovely maiden from,<l n="418>Syr, whenns ys that lovely may,who was serving in the hall today?<l n="419>That yn the halle served this day?Tell me if you may.”<l n="420>Tell me yyf hyt be thy wyll.Then Sir Kadore said, as I understand,

<l n="421>Then sayde syr Kadore, Y untherstonde,“She is an earl’s daughter from a faraway land<l n="422>Hyt ys an erles thowghter of ferre londe,who is beautiful to look at.<l n="423>That semely ys to sene,Truthfully I sent for her<l n="424>I sente after her, certeynlye,to nurture my children,<l n="425>To teche my chylderen curtesye,and to keep them company in their chamber.<l n="426>In chambur wyth hem to bene.She is the most erudite woman,<l n="427>She ys the konnyngest wommon,for sure, in all of Christendom,<l n="428>I trowe that be yn Crystendom,[judging by] the works I have seen.”<l n="429>Of werk that y have sene.Then the powerful sovereign said,<l n="430>Then sayde that ryche raye,“I will possess that fair maiden<l n="431>I wyll have that fayr may,and wed her as my queen.”<l n="432>And wedde her to my quene.The noble king, truthfully,

<l n="433>The nobull kyng, verament,sent for his mother<l n="434>After hys modyr he sent,to find out what she would say.<l n="435>To wyte what she wolde say.They hastily brought forth<l n="436>They browght forth hastelythat fair young woman Egaré;<l n="437>That fayr mayde Egarye,she was as bright as a summer’s day.<l n="438>She was bryghth as someres day,The fabric on her gleamed so brightly<l n="439>The cloth on her shon so bryght,when she was dressed in it,<l n="440>When she was theryn dyght,and [she was] herself a noble maiden.<l n="441>And her self a gentell may.The old queen immediately said:<l n="442>The olde qwene sayde anon,“I have never seen a woman<l n="443>I sawe never wommoneven half as magnificent!”<l n="444>Halvendell so gay!The old queen spoke unkind words

<l n="445>The olde quene spakke wordes unhende,and said: “Son, this is a fiend<l n="446>And sayde, Sone, thys ys a fende,in this costly dress!<l n="447>In this wordy wede,Since you have asked for my blessing:<l n="448>As thou lovest my blessynge,do not ever go through with this wedding.<l n="449>Make thou never this weddynge,Christ forbids you to do it!”<l n="450>Cryst hit de forbede!Then the powerful sovereign said:<l n="451>Then spakke the ryche ray,“Mother, I will possess this maiden!”<l n="452>Modyr, y wyll have this may,And he led her away.<l n="453>And forth gan her lede.The old queen, truthfully,<l n="454>The olde quene, for certayne,furiously went back home<l n="455>Turnede with ire hom agayne,and would not attend the wedding.<l n="456>And wolde not be at that dede.The king wed that radiant lady,

<l n="457>The kyng wedded that lady bryght,and great hospitality was arranged for there<l n="458>Grete purvyance ther was dyghth,in that beautiful hall.<l n="459>In that semely sale,Distinguished lords were served according to courtly protocol: dukes, earls, barons, and knights<l n="460>Grete lordes wer served aryght,of high and low rank.<l n="461>Duke, erle, baron and knyghth,Many common folk, truthfully, were there<l n="462>Both of grete and smale.and a large crowd it was,<l n="463>Myche folke for sothe ther was,as is told in the tale.<l n="464>And thereto an huge prese,There was all manner of things<l n="465>As hit ys tolde in tale,befitting a royal wedding,<l n="466>Ther was all maner thyng,and many a famous entertainer.<l n="467>That fell to a kyngus weddyng,When the eating was done<l n="468>And mony a ryche menstrall.the great lords—

<l n="469>When the mangery was done,who were beautiful to look at—soon departed.<l n="470>Grete lordes departed sone,The king departed with the queen.<l n="471>That semely were to see,Much love was between them,<l n="472>The kynge be laste with the qwene,and also joy and happiness.<l n="473>Moch love was hem betwene,She was well-mannered and delightful—<l n="474>And also game and gle ;I have never heard of such a lady before—<l n="475>She was curteys and swete,and they loved each other from their noble hearts.<l n="476>Such a lady herde y never of yete ;The lady who was both humble and compassionate<l n="477>They loved both with herte fre.conceived and soon was pregnant<l n="478>The lady that was both meke and mylde,as God willed it to be.<l n="479>Conceyved and wente with chylde,At that time, the King of France<l n="480>As god wolde hit sholde be.was assailed by many “Saracens”

<l n="481>The kyng of France, yn that tyme,and [thus] encumbered with distress;<l n="482>Was besette with many a Sarezyne,he sent for the King of “Galys”<l n="483>And cumbered all in tene ;and other lords of great worth<l n="484>And sente after the kyng of Galys,who were beautiful to look at.<l n="485>And other lordys of myche prys,The King of “Galys”, at that time,<l n="486>That semely were to sene.gathered men around him<l n="487>The kyng of Galys, in that tyde,in radiant and bright armor.<l n="488>Gedered men on every syde,Then the king said to Sir Kadore<l n="489>In armour bryght and shene ;and other lords that were present:<l n="490>Then sayde the kyng to Syr Kadore,“Take good care of my queen.”<l n="491>And other lordes that ther wore,The King of France spared nobody,<l n="492>Take good hede to my qwene.but sent for all of them:

<l n="493>The kyng of Fraunce spared none,kings, knights and clergy.<l n="494>But sent for hem everychone,The steward who was left at home<l n="495>Both kyng, knyghth and clerke ;to look after the queen [who was as] white as foam<l n="496>The stiward, * bylaft at home,did not join that mission.<l n="497>To kepe the qwene whyte as fome,She was pregnant […] ,<l n="498>He com not at that werke.for as long as it was God’s will,<l n="499>She wente with chylde, yn place,that beautiful one under her shift,<l n="500>As longe as goddes wyll was,until from her body<l n="501>That semely unther serke ;a beautiful and handsome child was delivered<l n="502>Thyll ther was of her body[who] had a double king’s mark.<l n="503>A fayr chyld borne, and a godele,They christened him with great honor,<l n="504>Hadde a dowbyll kynges marke.and called him Segramour;

<l n="505>They hit crystened wyth grete honour,that baby was of noble lineage.<l n="506>And called hym Segramour,Then the steward, Sir Kadore,<l n="507>Frely was that fode ;wrote a noble letter right away<l n="508>Then the steward syr Kadore,and crafted it well.<l n="509>A nobull letter made he thore,He crafted it in haste,<l n="510>And wrowghte hit all with gode.and sent it to his lord, the king,<l n="511>He wrowghte hit yn hyghynge,who was of noble lineage.<l n="512>And sente hit to his lorde the kynge,The messenger then went on his way.<l n="513>That gentyll was of blode ;He came by the king’s mother[‘s place]<l n="514>The messenger forth gan wende,and went into the castle.<l n="515>And with the kynges moder gan lende,He was received splendidly<l n="516>And yn to the castell he yode.and she eagerly asked him

<l n="517>He was resseyved rychely,how the queen had been faring.<l n="518>And she hym askede hastyly,“My Lady, she has given birth to<l n="519>How the qwene hadde spedde ;a beautiful male child, I am telling you truthfully, and she is lying in [child]bed.”<l n="520>“Madame, ther ys of her yborneFor this news, she gave him<l n="521>A fayr man chylde, y tell you beforne,a robe and forty shillings<l n="522>And she lyth in her bedde.”and had him richly clothed.<l n="523>She yaf hym, for that tydynge,She got him drunk on ale and wine<l n="524>A robe and fowrty shylynge,and when she saw that it was time,<l n="525>And rychely hym cladde :she led him to his bedroom.<l n="526>She made hym dronken of ale and wyne ;And when he had fallen asleep,<l n="527>And when she sawe that hit was tyme,the queen, who had an evil mind,<l n="528>Tho chambur she wold hym lede.went to the chamber.

<l n="529>And when he Ɨ was on slepe browght,She took his letter from him<l n="530>The qwene that was of wykked thowght,and then burnt it in a fire;<l n="531>Tho chambur gan she wende ;her machinations were unkind.<l n="532>Hys letter she toke hym fro,Maliciously, she made another letter<l n="533>In a fyre she brente hit do,and said that the queen had given birth to a devil<l n="534>Of werkes she was unhende.[and that] nobody dared to come close to her.<l n="535>Another letter she made with evyll,[That her son] had three heads:<l n="536>And sayde the qwene had born a devyll,a lion’s, a dragon’s, and a bear’s,<l n="537>Durst no mon come her hende.and was a foul, hairy fiend.<l n="538>Thre heddes hadde he thereIn the morning, when it was day,<l n="539>A lyon, a dragon, and a beere,the messenger went on his way,<l n="540>A fowll feltred fende.both on the roads and the paths,

<l n="541>On the morn, when hit was day,truthfully, as the story goes,<l n="542>The messenger wente on his way,until he came to where the king was encamped,<l n="543>Bothe by stye and strete,and he spoke sweet words.<l n="544>In trwe story as y say,He delivered the letter to the king;<l n="545>Tyll he come ther as the kynge laye,and as he read it, I understand,<l n="546>And speke wordes swete.[the king] let the tears stream down his face.<l n="547>He toke the kyng the lettur yn honde,And as he stood reading,<l n="548>And he hit redde, y untherstonde,he fell down, swooning;<l n="549>The teres down gan he lete.his heart was bleeding from sorrow.<l n="550>And as he stode yn redyng,Noble lords that stood beside him<l n="551>Downe he fell yn sowenyng,hastily helped the king up;<l n="552>For sorow his herte gan blede.in his heart, he was filled with sorrow.

<l n="553>Grete lordes that stonde hym by,He wept bitterly and said, “Alas,<l n="554>Toke up the kyng hastely,that I was ever born!<l n="555>In herte he was full woo ;That it should ever be like this.<l n="556>Sore he grette and sayde, Alas !Alas, that I was made a king<l n="557>That y ever man born was,and then wedded the fairest thing<l n="558>That hit ever so shullde be ;that may walk on earth.<l n="559>Alas! that y was made a kynge,That Jesus himself would ever send<l n="560>And sygh wedded the fayrest thyngsuch a foul, loathly fiend,<l n="561>That on erthe myght go ;to come between the two of us.”<l n="562>That evur Jhesu hymself wolde sende,When he saw it could not be helped,<l n="563>Such a fowle lothly fende,he made another letter,<l n="564>To come bytwene us too !and sealed it with his seal.

<l n="565>When he sawe hit myght no better be,He commanded that above all,<l n="566>Another letter then made he,the young lady was to be kept safe<l n="567>And seled hit with his sele ;until she had recovered [from the birth];<l n="568>He commanded yn al thynge,everybody, righteous or evil,<l n="569>To kepe well that lady yynge,was to serve her as she commanded<l n="570>Tyll she hadde her hele ;for better or worse.<l n="571>Bothe gode men and ylle,[The messenger] took the letter from his hands,<l n="572>To serve her at her wylle,and rode back along the same route<l n="573>Bothe yn wo and wele :via the king’s mother’s castle.<l n="574>He toke this letter of his honde,And then he stayed there all night;<l n="575>And rode thorow the same londe,he was received well and outfitted richly<l n="576>By the kynges modur castell.and he was not aware of any treason.

<l n="577>And then he dwelled ther all nyght,He made himself comfortable, perfectly at ease,<l n="578>He was resseyved and rychely dyght,with bread, ale, and wine,<l n="579>And wyst of no treson ,and that robbed him of his senses.<l n="580>He made hym well at ese and fyne,When he fell asleep<l n="581>Bothe of brede, ale, and wyne,the false queen looked for his letter,<l n="582>And that berafte hym his reson.she cast it into the fire<l n="583>When he was on slepe browht,and made another letter,<l n="584>The false qwene his letter sowghte ,[saying] that men should seize the lady<l n="585>In to the fyre she kaste hit downe ;and lead her out of town<l n="586>Another letter she lette make,and cast her into the sea<l n="587>That men sholde the lady take,in that robe of radiant hues,<l n="588>And lede her out of towne.along with her little child,

<l n="589>And putte her ynto the see,and let her have no allowance<l n="590>In that robe of ryche ble,for food or drink<l n="591>The lytyll chylde her wyth ;but drive her out of that country.<l n="592>And lette her have no spendyng,“Show her no mercy,<l n="593>For no mete ny for drynke,or you will be punished by death<l n="594>But lede her out of that kyth. Ɨalong with your own children and your wife!”<l n="595>Upon payn of chylde and wyfeThe messenger was completely unaware [of this]<l n="596>And also upon your owene lyfeand he rode home for many a mile<l n="597>Lette her have no gryth ;through forests and estates.<l n="598>The messenger knew no gyle,And when the messenger came home<l n="599>But rode hom mony a myle,the steward quickly took the letter<l n="600>By forest and by fryth.and started to read.

<l n="601>And when the messenger come home,He sighed heavily and said: “Alas,<l n="602>The steward toke the letter sone,certainly this is a foul case,<l n="603>And bygan to rede ;and a doleful deed!”<l n="604>Sore he syght and sayde, alas !And as he stood reading,<l n="605>Sertes this ys a fowle case,he fell down swooning;<l n="606>And a defull dede.his heart was bleeding from sorrow.<l n="607>And as he stode yn redyng,There was nobody, neither old nor young,<l n="608>He fell downe yn swounynge,who would not weep<l n="609>For sorow his hert gan blede ;for that worthy one underneath her dress.<l n="610>Ther was nother olde ny yynge,The lady heard the great clamour in the hall.<l n="611>That myghte forbere of wepynge,She called the steward<l n="612>For that worthy unther wede.and said: “What can this be about?
